contentrichtext.text: {{Infobox military conflict |conflict=Battle of Seneffe |image= [[File:Bataille de Seneffe de B.Gagneraux.JPG|300px]] |caption= The [[Henri Jules, Prince of Condé|Duke of Enghien]] saving his father, the [[Grand Condé]] at the battle of Seneffe: painting from 1786 by [[Bénigne Gagneraux]] |partof=the [[Franco-Dutch War]] |date=11 August 1674 |place=near [[Seneffe]], present-day [[Belgium]] |result= Tactical French victory; Allies retreat to fortified positions<ref>Lynn, p. 80-81</ref> |combatant1={{flagcountry|Kingdom of France}} |combatant2={{flag|Dutch Republic}}<br>{{flag|Holy Roman Empire}}<br>{{flag|Spain|1506}} |commander1={{flagicon|Kingdom of France}} [[Louis II de Bourbon, Prince de Condé|Prince de Condé]] |commander2={{flagicon|Dutch Republic}} [[William III of England|William III of Orange]] |strength1=30,000 infantry<br>14,200 cavalry<br>60 guns |strength2=40,000 infantry<br>22,000 cavalry<br>~70 guns |casualties1=10,000 dead, wounded, or captured<ref name="figures">Lynn, p. 126</ref> |casualties2=10,000 dead,<br>15,000 wounded,<br>5,000 captured<ref name="figures"/> }} {{Campaignbox Dutch War}} The '''Battle of Seneffe''' was fought on 11 August 1674 between French army under the command of [[Louis II de Bourbon, Prince de Condé]] and the [[Dutch Republic|Dutch]]-[[Holy Roman Empire|German]]-[[Spain|Spanish]] army under [[William III of England|William III of Orange]]. During the Franco-Dutch war, William III commanded a [[Dutch Republic|Dutch]]-[[Holy Roman Empire|German]]-[[Spain|Spanish]] army through the southern Netherlands into the territory of Northern France. France defended this area with an army under [[Louis II de Bourbon, Prince de Condé]]. For five weeks the two armies manoeuvred without getting into combat with each other. On the 10th of August, William III decided to head for Paris in order to force the enemy into fighting. Condé sent a detachment of about 500 horsemen to keep the Dutch vanguard busy near the village of Seneffe, blocking the advance of [[William III of England|William]]. In the meantime, Condé tried to surround the 60,000 allied troops with the 45,000 men at his disposal. The horsemen managed to keep the Dutch vanguard busy, but the envelopment of the main allied force failed. After ten hours Condé had 8,000 dead or wounded and [[William III of England|William]] - 11,000. Both armies retreated from the battlefield and although the battle was indecisive; both sides claimed victory. [[File:Réception du Grand Condé à Versailles (Jean-Léon Gérôme, 1878).png|thumb|left|300px|Reception of the [[Grand Condé]] at Versailles following his victory at Seneffe. Condé advances towards Louis XIV in a respectful manner with laurel wreaths on his path, while captured enemy flags are displayed on both sides of the stairs. It marked the end of Condé's exile, following his participation to the [[Fronde]].]] ==Notes== <div class="references-small"> <references/> </div> ==References== * Lynn, John A. ''The Wars of Louis XIV, 1667–1714.'' Longman, (1999). ISBN 0-582-05629-2 {{coord missing|Belgium}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Seneffe 1674}} [[Category:Conflicts in 1674]] [[Category:1674 in Europe]] [[Category:Battles involving France]] [[Category:Battles involving Spain]] [[Category:Battles involving Austria]] [[Category:Battles involving the Dutch Republic]] {{Austria-battle-stub}} {{France-battle-stub}} {{Netherlands-hist-stub}} {{Spain-battle-stub}}
